awd_titl_txt: Building New Pathways to Biotechnology Technician Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Madison, Wisconsin, region has a high concentration of jobs in bioscience industries.  For example, it ranks fourth in the nation for concentration of pharmaceutical industries.  The existing Biotechnology Program at Madison Area Technical College has a 90% job placement rate, but does not produce sufficient graduates to meet regional industry demands.  This project will establish a nine-credit Biotechnology Program for liberal arts and undeclared students at Madison Area Technical College.  By integrating biotechnology laboratory skills and career development experiences into the general biology curriculum, more students may be attracted to bioscience technician careers. The project will develop undergraduate research experiences, internships, and digital badges to assess and document student mastery of key biotechnology skills. The nine-credit certificate program, which includes coursework in basic laboratory techniques and concepts, will provide students with the knowledge and skills needed to gain employment in the biotechnology industry.  Offering this certificate program to liberal arts/undeclared students who are not in the biotechnology career pipeline has the potential to increase the pool of qualified biotech employees.  
 
This project involves a collaboration between the Biology department and Biotechnology associate degree program at the Madison Area Technical College, and the Wisconsin Crop Innovation Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.  These partners will develop and implement a bioscience curriculum with the unifying theme of food security. This curriculum will be designed to incorporate the core competencies of undergraduate biology education and core skill standards for bioscience technicians.  The project activities will provide liberal arts/undeclared students an opportunity at Madison Area Technical College to complete a biotechnology certificate and participate in digital badging system designed to communicate these skills to industry.  Partnership with the Wisconsin Crop Innovation Center will provide students with internship experiences to hone skills and make industry connections. These activities have the potential to increase the number of students who have skills in demand for biotechnology jobs, improve and grow academic and industry opportunities, and increase access to STEM careers for all students. Students and key academic advisors (high school teachers, guidance counselors and administration) will be able to learn more about the academic programming available for bioscience students and associated bioscience careers through newly developed "Bioscience Career Roadmaps."

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Award Title: Building New Pathways to Biotechnology Technician Careers

The NSF-ATE Award, Building New Pathways to Biotechnology Technician Careers, was developed to support students at Madison Area Technical College (Madison College), a Community and Technical college located in Madison, Wisconsin serving approximately 20,000 students across six campuses. This work was done in a partnership between the Madison College Biology Department, the Madison College Biotechnology program, and the Wisconsin Crop Innovation Center (WCIC). The overarching goal of this work was to create opportunities for students to learn about biotechnology and bioscience as a career option and have a viable pathway to introductory-level employment in bioscience and biotechnology.

The goals of this work included:

1. Embedding authentic research experiences into the first-year biology curriculum

2. Increasing access to STEM careers for Liberal Arts Transfer (LAT) students

3. Increasing the number of students with in-demand skills in biotechnology

4. Improving and expanding biotechnology academic and industry internship opportunities

5. Providing a curricular pathway to a biotechnology certificate program

All project goals were achieved. Authentic research experiences were developed and implemented for six biology courses. Since program implementation in 2019, over 700 Madison College biology students have participated in a course-based research experience (CUREs). A dedicated open research lab was established for students to participate in research outside the classroom in partnership with their faculty mentors. A campus-wide Student Research and Scholarly Activity Day was established in 2019.

Representatives from local biotechnology industry employers were consulted to understand the critical skills required for introductory-level careers. These skills were incorporated into the CUREs classroom experience and assessed using a new digital badging initiative. Partnerships were developed with Madison College Career and Employment Services (CES), and a new staff position was created to serve liberal arts transfer students to obtain internships. Over 30 students participated in internships at five different locations through this award. A new certificate for liberal arts transfer students was developed to provide a pathway to courses in the biotechnology technical program. This new certificate was challenging to implement and had a temporary delay due to COVID, but it was first offered in the Spring of 2021. Work is underway to expand excess to this and other technology certificate programs at Madison College.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Kitrina Carlson
